articles.headline: Solace and Fury as Schools React to Transgender Policy
articles.snippet: Conservatives called the Obama administration’s directive on school bathrooms an illegal overreach, while advocates for transgender rights hailed it as a breakthrough.
articles.abstract: Conservatives called the Obama administration’s directive on school bathrooms an illegal overreach, while advocates for transgender rights hailed it as a breakthrough.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — The Obama administration’s directive Friday on the use of school bathrooms and locker rooms by transgender students intensified the latest fierce battle in the nation’s culture wars, with conservatives calling it an illegal overreach that will put children in danger and advocates for transgender rights hailing it as a breakthrough for civil rights.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Biofuels Plant in Hawaii Is First to Be Certified as Sustainable
articles.snippet: An audit has resolved doubts in the industry, at least for one plant, about the products’ ultimate ability to reduce carbon emissions.
articles.abstract: An audit has resolved doubts in the industry, at least for one plant, about the products’ ultimate ability to reduce carbon emissions.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEAAU, Hawaii — The trucks roll in and out of the plant at a business park nestled near papaya farms and a forest preserve on the Big Island here, an operation that transforms waste cooking oils, animal fats, fruit and seeds into biodiesel fuel, nearly 13,000 gallons a day.

articles.headline: Pfizer Blocks the Use of Its Drugs in Executions
articles.snippet: The pharmaceutical giant’s move to clamp down on the distribution of its products closes off the last remaining open-market source of execution drugs.
articles.abstract: The pharmaceutical giant’s move to clamp down on the distribution of its products closes off the last remaining open-market source of execution drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical giant Pfizer announced on Friday that it had imposed sweeping controls on the distribution of its products to ensure that none are used in lethal injections, a step that closes off the last remaining open-market source of drugs used in executions.

articles.headline: Details Emerge on Global Bank Heists by Hackers
articles.snippet: The latest target appears to have been in Vietnam, and the intruders used tools similar to those used in a Sony Pictures hacking in 2014.
articles.abstract: The latest target appears to have been in Vietnam, and the intruders used tools similar to those used in a Sony Pictures hacking in 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just how securely are banks moving money around the world?
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Megyn Kelly, Contract Set to Expire Next Year, Is Primed for the Big Show
articles.snippet: The Fox anchor, whose contract is up for renewal next year, sees a chance to be the next Barbara Walters. A one-on-one with Donald Trump will set the stage.
articles.abstract: The Fox anchor, whose contract is up for renewal next year, sees a chance to be the next Barbara Walters. A one-on-one with Donald Trump will set the stage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barbara Walters is retired, Oprah Winfrey is running a network and Megyn Kelly sees an opening.

articles.headline: New Crowdfunding Rules Let the Small Fry Swim With Sharks
articles.snippet: Starting Monday, new regulations will permit anyone, not just the moneyed, to invest in small companies in exchange for a stake in the business.
articles.abstract: Starting Monday, new regulations will permit anyone, not just the moneyed, to invest in small companies in exchange for a stake in the business.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’ve always dreamed of being Mr. Wonderful from “Shark Tank,” now is your chance.

articles.headline: Crossing the Line: How Donald Trump Behaved With Women in Private
articles.snippet: Interviews reveal unwelcome advances, a shrewd reliance on ambition, and unsettling workplace conduct over decades.
articles.abstract: Interviews reveal unwelcome advances, a shrewd reliance on ambition, and unsettling workplace conduct over decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump had barely met Rowanne Brewer Lane when he asked her to change out of her clothes.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Megan Twohey

articles.headline: Brazil’s Graft-Prone Congress: A Circus That Even Has a Clown
articles.snippet: The legislature contains a dizzying cast of characters, and, by one count, more than half of its 594 members face legal challenges.
articles.abstract: The legislature contains a dizzying cast of characters, and, by one count, more than half of its 594 members face legal challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — One of Brazil’s longest-running spectacles features a dizzying array of characters whose theatrics appear on millions of television sets most nights.

articles.headline: Start-Ups Embrace Arbitration to Settle Workplace Disputes
articles.snippet: As new companies grow, they are relying on a tool used by big corporations to shield themselves from potentially expensive class-action court cases.
articles.abstract: As new companies grow, they are relying on a tool used by big corporations to shield themselves from potentially expensive class-action court cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tara Zoumer thought she had found her dream job when she was hired at WeWork, a $16 billion start-up that rents office space to young entrepreneurs. The walls were adorned with Pop Art. Neon light fixtures encouraged employees to “Hustle harder,” and there was beer on tap.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: For Obama, an Unexpected Legacy of Two Full Terms at War
articles.snippet: The president has approached conflict, and dealings with terror groups, as a chronic but manageable security challenge rather than an all-consuming national campaign.
articles.abstract: The president has approached conflict, and dealings with terror groups, as a chronic but manageable security challenge rather than an all-consuming national campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama came into office seven years ago pledging to end the wars of his predecessor, George W. Bush. On May 6, with eight months left before he vacates the White House, Mr. Obama passed a somber, little-noticed milestone: He has now been at war longer than Mr. Bush, or any other American president.

articles.headline: Squatters See a New Frontier in the Empty Homes of Las Vegas
articles.snippet: Foreclosed homes still pockmark Las Vegas, lingering signs of the housing crisis. But they do not always stay empty: Squatters move in, bringing crime with them.
articles.abstract: Foreclosed homes still pockmark Las Vegas, lingering signs of the housing crisis. But they do not always stay empty: Squatters move in, bringing crime with them.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — On a drive through this desert city, the blight from the housing collapse of eight years ago can be seen on almost every block: Overgrown yards and boarded-up windows identify the foreclosed and abandoned homes that still pockmark southern Nevada.

articles.headline: A Republican Congresswoman Has Personal Stake in Transgender Debate
articles.snippet: Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen of Florida, whose son is transgender, said her party was “lagging behind” on the issue.
articles.abstract: Representative Ileana Ros-Lehtinen of Florida, whose son is transgender, said her party was “lagging behind” on the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The day Rodrigo Heng-Lehtinen told his prominent parents about his new gender identity, he did so in a letter that he left on their bed. Then he grabbed a packed bag and, unsure of whether he would be welcomed back, went to a friend’s house to see if his family would love him or leave him.

articles.headline: Dying Infants and No Medicine: Inside Venezuela’s Failing Hospitals
articles.snippet: Supplies are lacking, electricity goes out, equipment is broken and patients lie in pools of blood as the country’s economic crisis has exploded into a public health emergency.
articles.abstract: Supplies are lacking, electricity goes out, equipment is broken and patients lie in pools of blood as the country’s economic crisis has exploded into a public health emergency.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Venezuela — By morning, three newborns were already dead.

articles.headline: Al Qaeda Turns to Syria, With a Plan to Challenge ISIS
articles.snippet: The group’s leadership in Pakistan has secretly dispatched seasoned veterans there to create an alternate headquarters and compete with the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: The group’s leadership in Pakistan has secretly dispatched seasoned veterans there to create an alternate headquarters and compete with the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Al Qaeda’s top leadership in Pakistan, badly weakened after a decade of C.I.A. drone strikes, has decided that the terror group’s future lies in Syria and has secretly dispatched more than a dozen of its most seasoned veterans there, according to senior American and European intelligence and counterterrorism officials.

articles.headline: Social Conservatives, However Reluctant, Are Warming to the Idea of Trump
articles.snippet: While Donald J. Trump may not have been their top choice, the adherents of socially conservative ideologies believe the alternative — Hillary Clinton — would be far worse.
articles.abstract: While Donald J. Trump may not have been their top choice, the adherents of socially conservative ideologies believe the alternative — Hillary Clinton — would be far worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Activists and leaders in the social conservative movement, after spending most of the past year opposing and condemning Donald J. Trump, are now moving to embrace his candidacy and are joining the growing number of mainstream Republicans who appear ready to coalesce around the party’s presumptive nominee.

articles.headline: Dick Wolf, Master of the Prime-Time Franchise, Leads NBC’s Comeback
articles.snippet: In this era of prestige television, “Law and Order: SVU” and other shows from Mr. Wolf prove that procedural dramas still work.
articles.abstract: In this era of prestige television, “Law and Order: SVU” and other shows from Mr. Wolf prove that procedural dramas still work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Dick Wolf’s “Law and Order” empire was coming apart.

articles.headline: Trying to Pin Down the Mosaic of Millennial Tastes
articles.snippet: Media companies are striving to appeal to a group with scattered tastes who crave novelty and individual experiences and who do not want to be a part of the herd.
articles.abstract: Media companies are striving to appeal to a group with scattered tastes who crave novelty and individual experiences and who do not want to be a part of the herd.
articles.lead_paragraph: The television industry is focusing a great deal of attention on millennials these days. Billions of dollars are in play, along with the reputations of industry executives who view this vast, diverse generation — generally defined as those born between 1977 and 1995 — as the hot consumers of choice in a bewilderingly changing business.

articles.headline: When TV Ads Go Subliminal With a Vengeance, We’ll Be to Blame
articles.snippet: When we started using new technology to watch shows on our own terms, without ads, we threw into question the modus operandi of a roughly $70 billion industry. A reckoning seems inevitable.
articles.abstract: When we started using new technology to watch shows on our own terms, without ads, we threw into question the modus operandi of a roughly $70 billion industry. A reckoning seems inevitable.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades the annual television industry ritual known as the upfronts has gone the same way.

articles.headline: Amazon Proves Infertile Soil for Unions, So Far
articles.snippet: High turnover may be one reason unions have made little progress at the e-commerce company, but some see manipulation and intimidation.
articles.abstract: High turnover may be one reason unions have made little progress at the e-commerce company, but some see manipulation and intimidation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In early April, Kellen Wadach, the general manager at Amazon’s warehouse in Middletown, Del., told hundreds of workers at the cavernous facility a troubling story about his family being abandoned by his father’s union.

articles.headline: Palestinian Museum Prepares to Open, Minus Exhibitions
articles.snippet: A $24 million building will open in the West Bank on Wednesday, but its inaugural display was suspended after a disagreement between its board and its director, who lost his position.
articles.abstract: A $24 million building will open in the West Bank on Wednesday, but its inaugural display was suspended after a disagreement between its board and its director, who lost his position.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRZEIT, West Bank — When the $24 million Palestinian Museum celebrates its opening on Wednesday, it will have almost everything: a stunning, contemporary new building; soaring ambitions as a space to celebrate and redefine Palestinian art, history and culture; an outdoor amphitheater; a terraced garden.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Rami Nazzal

articles.headline: Justices, Seeking Compromise, Return Contraception Case to Lower Courts
articles.snippet: The case was brought by religious groups that objected to having to provide insurance coverage for contraception for their female employees.
articles.abstract: The case was brought by religious groups that objected to having to provide insurance coverage for contraception for their female employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, in an unsigned unanimous opinion, announced on Monday that it would not rule in a major case on access to contraception, and instructed lower courts to consider whether a compromise was possible.
